newsitem.title: COLOMBIA: Bogota Metro work to start in 1998, Samper says.
newsitem.headline: Bogota Metro work to start in 1998, Samper says.

text.p: Colombian President Ernesto Samper, who is on an official visit to China, was quoted Tuesday as saying that work on the construction of a $2 billion Metro system would begin in Bogota in 1998.
The RCN radio network said Samper told reporters traveling with him that a $135 million investment by Beijing would help get the project off the ground.

Samper said the first stretch of the metropolitan train network would be a line from the town of Soacha, a short distance southwest of Bogota, followed by another heading west to the town of Facatativa and a third serving the capital's northern suburbs, RCN radio said.

Colombia's first Metro opened last November in the northwestern industrial city of Medellin. The 12-mile (30 km) network, consisting of two above-ground lines, took 12 years to build at a cost of $1.8 billion, twice the original estimate.
Transport experts say a Metro in Bogota would help relieve the capital's chronic traffic problems.
